content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
Two identical apartments. Same rent. One costs you
$1,200 more per year to live in.

How is this possible?

objectives.description: Understand different types of local taxes and how they fund schools, police, roads, and community services.
Compute property tax obligations using assessed values, millage rates, and exemptions.
Assess how local tax structures vary across jurisdictions and impact your total cost of living.
Compare tax rates and services across locations to make informed residency and housing decisions.

terms.definition: A tax levied on real estate by local governments, typically based on the assessed value of the property.
terms.example: A home assessed at $200,000 with a 3% tax rate pays $6,000 in annual property taxes.

terms.definition: The dollar value assigned to a property by a government assessor for calculating property taxes (often less than market value).
terms.example: In {{STATE_NAME}}, a $300,000 home is assessed at {{STATE_ASSESSMENT_PERCENTAGE}}% of market value.

terms.definition: The amount of tax per $1,000 of assessed property value. One mill = $1 per $1,000 of value.
terms.example: 25 mills = $25 per $1,000 = 2.5% tax rate. On a $200,000 assessed value = $5,000 tax.

terms.definition: A reduction in the assessed value of a primary residence, reducing the tax burden on homeowners.
terms.example: In {{STATE_NAME}}, a ${{STATE_HOMESTEAD_EXEMPTION}} exemption reduces your assessed value for tax purposes.

leftPanel.title: Your Tax Dollars at Work
paragraphs: Unlike federal taxes, local taxes stay in your community and fund the services that directly impact your daily life.
Property taxes are the #1 source of local government revenue, funding essential services you use every day.

highlightBox.text: Higher taxes often = better schools, safer neighborhoods, well-maintained roads. The question is: are you getting good value?

leftPanel.title: The Property Tax Formula
paragraphs: Step 1: Determine market value of property
Step 2: Apply assessment ratio (varies by state)
Step 3: Subtract any exemptions (homestead, etc.)
Step 4: Multiply by millage rate

highlightBox.text: Formula: (Assessed Value - Exemptions) √ó Millage Rate √∑ 1,000 = Annual Tax

layoutData.title: Beyond Property Taxes
paragraphs: Local governments may use multiple types of taxes. Your total local tax burden depends on where you live and how you spend.
bulletPoints: Property Tax: Primary local revenue source, based on real estate value
Local Sales Tax: Added on top of state sales tax (ranges 0-4%+)
Local Income Tax: Some cities tax resident income (up to 2-3%)
Special Assessments: Charges for local improvements (sidewalks, sewers)
Utility Taxes: Taxes on water, electric, gas services
Vehicle Registration: Local fees added to state registration

keyPoint.text: The same home in different jurisdictions can cost thousands more annually in local taxes‚Äîalways calculate the TOTAL burden.

leftPanel.title: Property Tax Adds to Monthly Payment
paragraphs: When you buy a home, your mortgage payment isn't the whole story. Property taxes are typically escrowed‚Äîadded to your monthly payment.
A $1,500 mortgage can become $1,900+ when property taxes (and insurance) are included.

highlightBox.text: Even renters pay‚Äîlandlords factor property taxes into rent prices. High-tax areas = higher rents, all else being equal.

content.headerTitle: Why Local Taxes Matter for Your Future

layoutData.title: Three Big Decisions Affected by Local Taxes
paragraphs: Understanding local tax structures is essential for making smart financial decisions throughout your life:
bulletPoints: Where to Rent: Factor in local sales taxes and services‚Äînot just rent
Job Offer Comparisons: A higher salary in a high-tax city might leave you with LESS money
Home Purchases: Property taxes add hundreds to monthly costs‚Äîyou may afford less house than you think
Voting Decisions: School levies and bond issues directly affect your tax bill
Retirement Planning: Some retirees relocate specifically for lower property taxes
Business Location: Entrepreneurs consider local taxes when choosing where to operate

keyPoint.text: The key is doing the math BEFORE you make the decision‚Äînot discovering high taxes after you've committed.

leftPanel.title: Even Neighboring Cities Differ
paragraphs: Tax rates vary dramatically between jurisdictions‚Äîeven within {{STATE_NAME}}. A home that seems affordable based on price alone can become financially stressful once property taxes are factored in.
Same $280,000 home in {{STATE_NAME}}:
‚Ä¢ {{STATE_HIGH_TAX_CITY}}: {{STATE_HIGH_TAX_MILLAGE}} mills
‚Ä¢ {{STATE_MEDIUM_TAX_CITY}}: {{STATE_MEDIUM_TAX_MILLAGE}} mills
‚Ä¢ {{STATE_LOW_TAX_CITY}}: {{STATE_LOW_TAX_MILLAGE}} mills

highlightBox.text: The difference between highest and lowest millage rates can mean thousands of dollars per year!

scenario.name: Mia Compares Two Apartments
paragraphs: Mia, 19, is choosing her first apartment in {{STATE_NAME}}. She earns $38,000 and spends about $1,000/month on taxable purchases.
Apartment A ({{STATE_HIGH_TAX_CITY}}): $850/month rent, {{STATE_HIGH_COMBINED_SALES_TAX}}% combined sales tax
Apartment B ({{STATE_LOW_TAX_CITY}}): $900/month rent, {{STATE_LOW_COMBINED_SALES_TAX}}% combined sales tax
The sales tax difference on $1,000/month affects her true cost of living.

scenario.name: The Rodriguez Family Home Purchase
paragraphs: Carlos and Maria are teachers earning $85,000 combined in {{STATE_NAME}}. They're choosing between two homes:
Home A ({{STATE_HIGH_TAX_CITY}}): $280,000 ‚Ä¢ {{STATE_HIGH_TAX_MILLAGE}} mills ‚Ä¢ School rating: 9/10
Home B ({{STATE_LOW_TAX_CITY}}): $265,000 ‚Ä¢ {{STATE_LOW_TAX_MILLAGE}} mills ‚Ä¢ School rating: 7/10
Home B saves $15,000 on price + lower annual taxes. Over 30 years, property tax savings add up significantly!
But as teachers who value education, they chose Home A‚Äîthe excellent schools are worth it to them.
